text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chocolate souffle
that's right valentine's Day is just
around the corner and there's nothing
that's gonna impress the object of your
desire more than a perfectly made
chocolate souffle and of course I mean
in the context of food being super rich
and really attractive probably would be
more impressive but as far as turning
out a dessert that your lover will love
this has a proven track record of being
very effective so with that let's go
ahead get started and before we actually
get to the soufflé batter we need to
prep our ramekins and all that's gonna
involve is lightly brushing them with
melted butter and we're gonna want to
make sure we apply that all over
including all the way to the top and
then what we'll do once that set is dust
the inside with sugar so we'll go ahead
and dump in about a tablespoon of white
sugar and what we'll do is pick it up
and sort of rotate it around like this
and not only is this move going to let
that sugar adhere to that butter but as
you can see any excess should spill out
so I went ahead and did that to both
ramekins because this recipe is gonna
make two portions at which point we can
actually start making our soufflé batter
and what I like to do first is break up
some dark chocolate into a metal mixing
bowl which I'm going to place over some
hot water not boiling not simmering just
hot and I'm gonna explain why in a
minute and then once that said we can
move on to believe it or not making a
roux so we'll go ahead and melt a little
bit of butter over medium heat and once
that's melted we'll go ahead and stir in
some all-purpose flour and we will whisk
that in and cook this on medium heat for
about a minute and even though we're
doing this for a dessert and not some
kind of savory sauce we're gonna use the
exact same technique which means as soon
as we've cooked our Roux for about a
minute we're gonna reduce our heat down
to low and we're gonna whisk in our cold
milk and yes it has to be cold because
as we all know cold milk hot roux no
lumps ever
all right so we'll reduce our heat and
whisk in our cold milk and as soon as
that gets mixed in and it comes back to
temperature it's gonna thicken up
quickly
I said quickly there we go so we'll just
whisk that over low heat until it
smoothes out and thickens up like this
at which point we're going to turn off
the heat and quickly transfer that into
our chocolate so let's lose the whisk
and we'll use a spatula to transfer this
end
and then what we'll do before we stir
this together is add a couple optional
ingredients which for me personally are
mandatory and those would be a pinch of
salt as well as a very very small shake
of cayenne okay only we should know it's
in there and then what we'll do at this
point is grab our spatula and give this
a quick mix we also need to add an egg
yolk to this but I do like to give this
mixture a quick stir before I add it in
then once we have that fairly well
combined as I just said we'll toss in a
yolk and basically once we have that
mixed in our souffle base is done and we
can move on to the last component which
is whipping the egg whites oh by the way
the reason I like to keep this bowl set
over hot water is because chocolate and
butter harden up is they cool so by
simply leaving this over some hot water
while we do our meringue we don't have
to worry about this getting too stiff
which might make it hard to incorporate
the whites and again the water doesn't
need to be simmering just hot so we'll
go ahead and leave our chocolate mixture
right there and we will start our
meringue by adding two large egg whites
to a mixing bowl along with a pinch of
cream of tartar which is an acidic
powder that helps stabilize the whites
it's optional and I'll touch on that in
the blog post and then we're also going
to add some sugar but not quite yet okay
we want to whisk these whites about
halfway before we start adding that and
you'll hear some people describe this as
the ribbon stage and that's because that
ribbon of egg whites dripping off the
whisk stays on the surface for about a
second before disappearing and then what
we'll do once it's reached this point is
that our sugar in three or four
additions so we'll sprinkle some in
we'll whisk it for about 30 seconds or
so and after three or four additions our
sugar will be gone at which point we're
simply going to continue whisking until
we have beautiful but not too stiff
peaks okay I think that's a very common
mistake with souffles people over beat
these egg whites okay so once our sugars
been introduced we really want to start
paying attention and while we do want
Peaks that hold their shape we don't
want to go so far that they start
looking dry and granular so I like to go
until I have something that resembles
sort of a stiff shaving cream okay so
these were just about perfect and I gave
him a few more seconds until they looked
exactly like that and then once that's
been accomplished what we'll do is
transfer in about 40% of those egg
whites into our chocolate mixture and
we'll use our spatula to mix that in and
light that mixture up and
most recipes say to add in half but I'd
like to do a little less than that with
his first addition but anyway I'm gonna
go ahead and add just under half my egg
whites and we'll use our spatula to go
ahead and stir that in in case you're
wondering why we're not folding and
we're using more of an aggressive
stirring motion well that's because this
first edition is to simply prep this
mixture so that we can incorporate the
rest of the egg whites without deflating
the mixture too much so we will go ahead
and stir in just under half our egg
whites as shown at which point we can
transfer in the rest of the egg whites
and now is when we're gonna use the old
folding technique and all that means is
take your spatula and fold batter from
the bottom up over the top going around
and kind of a circular motion and we're
basically going to continue using that
method until all the egg whites have
disappeared
do not continue mixing once that white
disappears okay so that is perfect right
there
and once our soufflé batter sat we'll
simply transfer that into our ramekins
ideally it's gonna come right up to
where that lip starts but if you have
extra batter you can fill them all the
way to the top it should still work and
then once our batter has been
transferred into our ramekins as you can
see I'm gonna place that on a sheet pan
and if we have any drip edge we will
clean that up not only so that it looks
neat but sometimes if you leave drips on
the edge it won't rise straight so we
will clean off our ramekins if need be
and no do not give it the whole tap a
tappa not appropriate here so we will
clean those up and place them on a pan
at which point they're ready to bake so
let's go ahead and transfer these into
the center of a 375 degree oven for
about 12 to 15 minutes or until they
look like this check it out those look
gorgeous
but we have no time to admire them
because souffles fall as soon as they
come out of the oven so before I plate
up I'm gonna quickly garnish these by
dusting over some cocoa and yes most
people do use powdered sugar for this
but of course that's up to you you are
after all the Tina Fey of your chocolate
souffle
not to mention especially on Valentine's
Day you're also the Tina Fey of getting
lots of compliments so go ahead and use
the powdered sugar if you think it looks
better but I'm a cocoa guy from way back
and as soon as those get dusted we'll go
ahead and transfer those to a plate at
which point we can grab a spoon and
start enjoying these
hopefully with another person or two we
don't judge but anyway let me go ahead
and dig in and these really did come out
perfect okay for me the ideal texture
for chocolate souffle is something
that's right in the middle between a
chocolate cake and a chocolate mousse
okay not too wet not too dry not too
Airy not too dense and for me this
really was right in that sweet spot pun
intended and by the way I will at this
point admit to not being a huge
chocolate souffle fan personally there
are chocolate delivery systems I do
prefer but that's sort of beside the
point because when it comes to serving a
chocolate dessert
it's going to thoroughly impress and by
impress I mean seduce the object of your
desires it really is hard to beat a
perfectly executed chocolate souffle
especially when you consider there's not
that many ingredients and contrary to
popular belief the technique is actually
pretty simple so whether you're gonna
make this for Valentine's Day or another
special occasion I really do hope you
give this a try soon so head over to

amounts have more info as usual and as
always enjoy
